news.headline: Trump administration moves to overrule state laws protecting credit reports from medical debt
news.summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has drafted what’s known as an interpretative rule. It says the FCRA should preempt any state laws or regulations when it comes to how debt should be reported. More than a dozen states like New York and Delaware prohibit the reporting of medical debt.
news.article_text:
NEW YORK (AP) — The Trump administration is moving to overrule any state laws that may protect consumers’ credit reports from medical debt and other debt issues.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has drafted what’s known as an interpretative rule related to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, interpreting the law in a way that says the FCRA should preempt any state laws or regulations when it comes to how debt should be reported to the credit bureaus like Experian, Equifax and Trans Union.

news.summary: Hormel Foods will retain a 49% interest, according to a statement, which did not disclose the financial terms of the deal.
news.article_text:
Credit: Jenari/Shutterstock.com

Hormel Foods is spinning off its Justin’s brand of nut butters and chocolate snacks through an investment agreement with Forward Consumer Partners.

In a transaction that is expected to close by the year-end, the New York-based private-equity firm is taking a 51% stake in Justin’s, which will become a standalone company with a new CEO.

Hormel Foods will retain a 49% interest, according to a statement, which did not disclose the financial terms of the deal.

NEW YORK (AP) — The Trump administration is moving to overrule any state laws that may protect consumers’ credit reports from medical debt and other debt issues.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has drafted what’s known as an interpretative rule related to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, interpreting the law in a way that says the FCRA should preempt any state laws or regulations when it comes to how debt should be reported to the credit bureaus like Experian, Equifax and Trans Union.

news.summary: Hormel Foods will retain a 49% interest, according to a statement, which did not disclose the financial terms of the deal.
news.article_text:
Credit: Jenari/Shutterstock.com

Hormel Foods is spinning off its Justin’s brand of nut butters and chocolate snacks through an investment agreement with Forward Consumer Partners.

In a transaction that is expected to close by the year-end, the New York-based private-equity firm is taking a 51% stake in Justin’s, which will become a standalone company with a new CEO.

Hormel Foods will retain a 49% interest, according to a statement, which did not disclose the financial terms of the deal.

all.news_summary: Shares of the embattled health insurer  Centene  jumped almost 8% on Wednesday after medical costs for its Medicaid plans came in below expectations, leaving it with better-than-expected third quarter results.  Shares plummeted 40% in a single day in early July when the company withdrew its 2025 financial guidance, citing worries about the plans it offers on the Affordable Care Act exchanges.  Since then, the stock has been “bouncing near the bottom like a pogo stick in an infinity pool,” as  Mizuho  healthcare equity strategist Jared Holz put it in an email to investors early Wednesday.

news.headline: Insurer Centene Stock Spikes on Earnings. There’s Still a Long Road to Recovery
news.summary: Shares of the embattled health insurer  Centene  jumped almost 8% on Wednesday after medical costs for its Medicaid plans came in below expectations, leaving it with better-than-expected third quarter results.  Shares plummeted 40% in a single day in early July when the company withdrew its 2025 financial guidance, citing worries about the plans it offers on the Affordable Care Act exchanges.  Since then, the stock has been “bouncing near the bottom like a pogo stick in an infinity pool,” as  Mizuho  healthcare equity strategist Jared Holz put it in an email to investors early Wednesday.
